definitions_glossary.planck_mass: The fundamental mass scale √(ℏc/G) ≈ 2.2 × 10⁻⁸ kg where quantum and gravitational effects become equally important
definitions_glossary.compton_wavelength: λ_C = ℏ/(mc), the quantum mechanical 'size' associated with a particle of mass m
definitions_glossary.schwarzschild_radius: r_S = 2Gm/c², the gravitational radius defining the event horizon for mass m
definitions_glossary.gravitational_coupling: α_G = Gm²/(ℏc), dimensionless measure of gravitational interaction strength
definitions_glossary.quantum_gravity_scale: Energy/mass scale where quantum corrections to gravity become order unity
definitions_glossary.unification_scale: Energy scale where fundamental forces converge in grand unified theories
definitions_glossary.black_hole_formation: Process by which sufficient mass-energy in a region creates an event horizon

key_relationships.description: Compton wavelength of Planck mass equals Planck length
Schwarzschild radius of Planck mass equals twice Planck length
Gravitational coupling constant equals unity at Planck mass

scale_comparisons.description: Planck mass is 10 billion times heavier than a proton
Planck mass is 10 trillion times heavier than an electron
Mass of a flea egg or a small grain of sand
Planck mass is 100 million times heavier than the heaviest known elementary particle

definition.@value: The fundamental mass scale √(ℏc/G) ≈ 2.176 × 10⁻⁸ kg where quantum mechanics and gravity become equally important, characterized by Compton wavelength equaling Schwarzschild radius

scopeNote.@value: Central to quantum gravity, black hole physics, particle physics unification theories, and understanding the quantum-gravitational mass scale

learning_objectives: Define Planck mass and understand its unique macroscopic nature
Explain the condition λ_C = r_S that defines Planck mass
Understand why Planck mass represents quantum-gravitational unification scale
Recognize the significance for black hole physics and particle theory
Calculate gravitational coupling α_G at Planck mass scale
common_errors: Thinking Planck mass is microscopic like other Planck units (it's macroscopic)
Confusing Planck mass with elementary particle masses (particles are much lighter)
Assuming Planck mass objects exist in nature (none observed, but possible in extreme conditions)
physics_insights: Planck mass is macroscopic because it has positive powers of both ℏ and c
At m = m_P, quantum spread (λ_C) equals gravitational size (r_S) at ℓ_P scale
α_G = 1 at Planck mass means gravity becomes 'strong' like other forces
Hierarchy problem: Why is electroweak scale (10² GeV) so far below Planck scale (10¹⁹ GeV)?
Black holes with m < m_P have r_S < ℓ_P, entering pure quantum gravity regime
